title: 'The Power of the Dog' Leads Oscar Nominations With 12 Nods; The 2022 Academy Awards are set for March, following another year in which the pandemic reshaped moviegoing
text:
The Full List of Nominees

* 2022 Academy Award contenders

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences committed to a field of 10 nominees for best picture, instead of a number that fluctuated from year to year. The goal was to capture a broader range of films in the most prestigious category.

The nominees for best picture are: "Belfast," "CODA," "Don't Look Up," "Drive My Car," "Dune," "King Richard," "Licorice Pizza," "Nightmare Alley," "The Power of the Dog" and "West Side Story."

Now the field is set for a second Oscars saddled with the baggage of Covid-19. The pandemic continues to force the issue of what movies people actually want to watch, and where. Hollywood's biggest night is the focal point of a debate about the value of movies, both commercially and as a source of common ground in culture. In 2021 the Oscars went from a ritual of arguable relevance to one in real crisis, with a 58% drop in viewers.

Kristen Stewart scored her first nomination, for best actress in a leading role for her turn as a beleaguered Princess Diana in "Spencer." The other nominees were Jessica Chastain ("The Eyes of Tammy Faye"), Olivia Colman ("The Lost Daughter"), Penélope Cruz ("Parallel Mothers") and Nicole Kidman ("Being the Ricardos").

The nominees for best actor in a leading role were Javier Bardem ("Being the Ricardos"), Benedict Cumberbatch ("The Power of the Dog"), Andrew Garfield ("tick, tick…BOOM!"), Will Smith ("King Richard") and Denzel Washington ("The Tragedy of Macbeth").

SHARE YOUR THOUGHTS

Which nominees would you like to see win an Oscar this year, and who do you feel was overlooked? Join the conversation below.

Ms. Campion, first nominated for best director for her 1993 film "The Piano," became the first woman ever to be nominated twice in the category with "The Power of the Dog." Other directors nominated were Kenneth Branagh ("Belfast"), Ryusuke Hamaguchi ("Drive My Car"), Paul Thomas Anderson ("Licorice Pizza") and Mr. Spielberg ("West Side Story").

The best-picture field was split between films that received a traditional theatrical release and those on major streaming platforms.

"Belfast," a black-and-white family drama set in Northern Ireland in 1969, took a textbook Oscar path, playing in theaters since mid-November.

"West Side Story" had been held over from 2020 in hopes of it making a big splash upon release in theaters in December. The musical won over critics and Oscar voters alike but fell flat at the box office. Director Guillermo del Toro's noir thriller "Nightmare Alley" also struggled in theaters but emerged with four Oscar nominations.

Among streamers, Apple Inc. landed its first Oscar nominations in the splashiest categories. Best-picture nominee "CODA," a coming-of-age story involving a deaf family, also earned nominations for supporting actor Troy Kotsur, the first deaf male actor to be nominated for an Oscar.

Mr. Kotsur is the second deaf performer ever to be nominated for an Oscar in acting. The first was his co-star in the film, Marlee Matlin, who won best actress for "Children of a Lesser God" in 1987. Writer-director Siân Heder also got a nod for best adapted screenplay for "CODA," which stands for "child of deaf adults."

Apple, which made its Oscar debut last year, also secured three nominations for "The Tragedy of Macbeth," including Mr. Washington's 10th career Oscar nomination.

"Dune" and "King Richard" reflect many of the issues facing the industry. Warner Bros. gave both films a hybrid release in theaters and on streaming service HBO Max—a controversial strategy the studio applied to its entire 2021 movie slate. The move caused friction with filmmakers and this week resulted in a lawsuit against Warner Bros. by the co-producer of "The Matrix Resurrections."

Many of this year's top nominees came out late last year, just as the Omicron variant was squelching the industry's hopes of enticing grown-up audiences back to theaters for anything other than superhero pictures.

They included "Licorice Pizza," a film Mr. Anderson wrote and directed, about an odd-couple relationship in the 1970s. It was nominated for best picture, director and original screenplay.

In recent years the Academy has aggressively enlarged its voting body, with big increases among members outside the U.S. That expansion might have factored into the strong showing for certain international films, especially "Drive My Car," from Japan. Championed by critics, the three-hour film adapted from a Haruki Murakami story received four nominations, including nods for best adapted screenplay and international feature.

"The Worst Person in the World," which chronicles four years in the life of a young woman in Norway, nabbed a best original screenplay nod. The story from director Joachim Trier and Eskil Vogt edged out Hollywood contenders including Aaron Sorkin's "Being the Ricardos" script about Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz.

"Spider-Man" dominated pop culture and defied pandemic trends to become one of the highest-grossing films ever. Yet it failed to land in any of the top Oscar categories, despite a push for awards respect by Sony Pictures and Marvel Studios. The blockbuster received a nod for visual effects but none in high-profile categories that might help entice more viewers to ABC's telecast in March.

Perhaps the biggest hit out of Hollywood other than "Spider-Man" was the song "We Don't Talk About Bruno," from Disney's "Encanto." The tune wasn't nominated because the studio had submitted a different song from the movie for awards consideration—the ballad "Dos Oruguitas"—before "Bruno" exploded in popularity across TikTok.

"Dos Oruguitas" was nominated for best original song. "Encanto" was also nominated in the categories of best animated feature and original score.
